{{flag|Zimbabwe}} |iso1 = tn |iso2 = tsn |iso3 = tsn |lingua = 99-AUT-eg |glotto=tswa1253 |glottorefname=Tswana }} {{Infobox NC name|Motswana|Batswana|Setswana|Botswana|The Tswana Language}} [[File:South Africa Tswana speakers proportion map.svg|thumb|Geographical distribution of Setswana in South Africa: proportion of the population that speaks Setswana at home. {{columns |col1= {{legend|#EDF8E9|0–20%}} {{legend|#BAE4B3|20–40%}} {{legend|#74C476|40–60%}} |col2= {{legend|#31A354|60–80%}} {{legend|#006D2C|80–100%}}}}]] [[File:South Africa Tswana speakers density map.svg|thumb|Geographical distribution of Setswana in South Africa: density of Setswana home-language speakers. {{columns |col1= {{legend|#ffffcc|<1 /km²}} {{legend|#ffeda0|1–3 /km²}} {{legend|#fed976|3–10 /km²}} {{legend|#feb24c|10–30 /km²}} {{legend|#fd8d3c|30–100 /km²}} |col2= {{legend|#fc4e2a|100–300 /km²}} {{legend|#e31a1c|300–1000 /km²}} {{legend|#bc0026|1000–3000 /km²}} {{legend|#800026|>3000 /km²}}}}]] The '''Tswana language''' or '''Setswana''' is spoken in [[Southern Africa]] by about five million people. It is a [[Bantu languages|Bantu language]] belonging to the [[Niger–Congo languages|Niger–Congo language family]] within the [[Sotho-Tswana languages|Sotho-Tswana]] branch of [[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone S|Zone S (S.30)]], and is closely related to the [[Northern Sotho language|Northern]] and [[Sotho language|Southern Sotho]] languages, as well as the [[Kgalagadi language]] and the [[Lozi language]]. Tswana is an official language and [[lingua franca]] of [[Botswana]]. The majority of Tswana-speakers are found in the north of South Africa, where four million people speak the language and an urbanised variety which is part slang and not the formal Setswana, known as [[Pretoria Sotho|Pretoria Tswana]], is the principal language of that city. The three South African provinces with the most speakers are [[Gauteng]] (circa 11%) and [[Northern Cape]] and [[North West (South African province)|North West]] (over 70%). Until 1994, South African Tswana people were notionally citizens of [[Bophuthatswana]], one of the [[bantustan]]s of the [[apartheid]] regime. The Setswana language in the Northwest Province has variations in which it is spoken according to the tribes found in the Tswana culture [Bakgatla, Barolong, Bakwena, Batlhaping, Bahurutshe, Bafokeng to name a few] the written language remains the same. Although Tswana is spoken mostly in South Africa and Botswana, a small number of speakers are also found in [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Namibia]]; respectively, an unknown number of people and about 10,000 people speak the language there. == History == The first European to describe the Tswana language was the [[Germans|German traveller]] [[Hinrich Lichtenstein|H. Lichtenstein]], who lived among the [[Tswana people]] [[Batlhaping tribe|Batlhaping]] in 1806, although his work was not published until 1930. He mistakenly regarded Tswana as a [[dialect]] of the [[Xhosa language]], and the name he used for the language ''"Beetjuana"'' may also have covered the [[Northern Sotho language|Northern]] and [[Sotho language|Southern Sotho languages]]. The first major work on the Tswana language was carried out by the British [[missionary]] [[Robert Moffat (missionary)|Robert Moffat]], who had also lived among the [[Batlhaping tribe|Batlhaping]], and published ''Bechuana Spelling Book'' and ''A Bechuana Catechism'' in 1826. In the following years he published several other [[books of the Bible]] and in 1857 he was able to publish a complete translation of the Bible.{{Harvnb|Janson|Tsonope|1991|pp=36–37}} The first grammar of the Tswana language was published in 1833 by the missionary [[James Archbell]], although it was modelled on a Xhosa grammar. The first grammar of Tswana which regarded it as a separate language from Xhosa (but still not as a separate language from the Northern- and Southern Sotho languages) was published by the French missionary [[E. Casalis]] in 1841. He changed his mind later, and in a publication from 1882 he noted that the Northern and Southern Sotho languages were distinct from Tswana.{{Harvnb|Janson|Tsonope|1991|pp=38–39}} [[Sol Plaatje|Solomon Plaatje]], a South African intellectual and [[linguist]], was one of the first writers to extensively write in and about the Tswana language. == Phonology == === Vowels === The [[vowel|vowel inventory]] of Tswana can be seen below.{{Harvnb|University of Botswana|2001|p=16}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" | ! {{IPA|/h/}} |- ! colspan="2" | [[Trill consonant|Trill]] | | '''{{angle bracket|r}}'''
{{IPA|/r/}} | | | | | | |- ! colspan="2" | [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | '''{{angle bracket|w}}'''
{{IPA|/w/}} | | '''{{angle bracket|l}}'''
{{IPA|/l/}} | | '''{{angle bracket|y}}'''
{{IPA|/j/}} | | | |} The [[consonant]] {{IPA|/d/}} is merely an [[allophone]] of {{IPA|/l/}}, when the latter is followed by the [[vowel]]s {{IPA|/i/}} or {{IPA|/u/}}.{{Harvnb|University of Botswana|2001|p=3}} Two more sounds, '''v''' {{IPA|/v/}} and '''z''' {{IPA|/z/}}, exist only in loanwords. Tswana also has three [[click consonant]]s, but these are only used in [[interjection]]s or [[ideophones]], and tend only to be used by the older generation, and are therefore falling out of use. The three click consonants are the [[dental click]] {{IPA|/ǀ/}}, orthographically {{angle bracket|c}}; the [[lateral click]] {{IPA|/ǁ/}}, orthographically {{angle bracket|x}}; and the [[palatal click]] {{IPA|/ǃ/}}, orthographically {{angle bracket|q}}.{{Harvnb|University of Botswana|2001|pp=11–12}} There are some minor [[dialect|dialectal variations]] among the consonants between speakers of Tswana. For instance, {{IPA|/χ/}} is realised as either {{IPA|/x/}} or {{IPA|/h/}} by many speakers; {{IPA|/f/}} is realised as {{IPA|/h/}} in most dialects; and {{IPA|/tɬ/}} and {{IPA|/tɬʰ/}} are realised as {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/tʰ/}} in northern dialects.{{Harvnb|University of Botswana|2001|pp=14–15}} === Stress === [[stress (linguistics)|Stress]] is fixed in Tswana and thus always falls on the [[ultima (linguistics)|penult]] of a word, although some [[compound (linguistics)|compounds]] may receive a secondary stress in the first part of the word. The [[syllable]] on which the stress falls is lengthened. Thus, [[mosadi]] is realised as {{IPA|[mʊ̀ˈsáːdì]}}.{{Harvnb|University of Botswana|2001|p=32}} === Tone === Tswana has two [[tone (linguistics)|tones]], high and low, although the latter has a much wider distribution in words than the former. Tones are not marked [[orthography|orthographically]] which may lead to ambiguity.{{Harvnb|University of Botswana|2001|pp=31–32}} : '''go bua''' {{IPA|/χʊ búa/}} ''"to speak"'' : '''go bua''' {{IPA|/χʊ bua/}} ''"to skin an animal"'' : '''o bua Setswana''' {{IPA|/ʊ́búa setswána/}} ''"He speaks Setswana"'' : '''o bua Setswana''' {{IPA|/ʊbúa setswána/}} ''"You speak Setswana"'' An important feature of the tones is the so-called spreading of the high tone. If a [[syllable]] bears a high tone, the following two syllables will also get high tones, unless they are at the end of the word.{{Harvnb|University of Botswana|2001|p=34}} : '''simolola''' {{IPA|/símʊlʊla/}} > {{IPA|/símʊ́lʊ́la/}} ''"to begin"'' : '''simologêla''' {{IPA|/símʊlʊχɛla/}} > {{IPA|/símʊ́lʊ́χɛla/}} ''"to begin for/at"'' == Grammar == === Nouns === [[Noun]]s in Tswana are grouped into nine [[noun class]]es and one subclass, each having different [[prefix]]es. The nine classes and their respective prefixes can be seen below, along with a short note regarding the common characteristics of most nouns within their respective classes.{{Harvnb|Cole|1955|pp=68–69}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! Class ! Singular ! Plural ! Characteristics |- ! 1. | mo- | ba- | align="left" | ''Persons'' |- ! 1a. | – | bô- | align="left" | ''Names, kinship, animals'' |- ! 2. | mo- | me-
ma- | rowspan="3" align="left" | ''Miscellaneous
(including bodyparts, tools,
instruments, animals, trees, plants)'' |- ! 3. | le- | ma- |- ! 4. | se- | di- |- ! 5. | n-
m-
ny-
ng- | rowspan="2" | din-
dim-
diny-
ding- | align="left" | ''Animals
(but also miscellaneous)'' |- ! 6. | lo- | align="left" | ''Miscellaneous
(including a number of collective nouns)'' |- ! 7. | bo- | ma- | align="left" | ''Abstract nouns'' |- ! 8. | colspan="2" | go- | align="left" | ''Infinitive forms of verbs'' |- ! 9. | colspan="2" | fa-
go-
mo- | align="left" | ''Adverbs'' |} Some nouns may be found in several classes. For instance, many class 1 nouns are also found in class 1a, class 3, class 4, and class 5.{{Harvnb|Cole|1955|p=70}} == References == === Notes === {{Reflist}} === General === * {{Citation | last = Cole | first = Desmond | authorlink = Desmond Cole | title = An Introduction to Tswana Grammar | year = 1955}} * {{Citation | last1 = Janson | first1 = Tore | author1-link = Tore Janson | last2 = Tsonope | first2 = Joseph | author2-link = Joseph Tsonope | title = Birth of a National Language: The History of Setswana | year = 1991 | isbn = 0-435-91620-3}} * {{Citation | author = [[University of Botswana]] | title = The Sound System of Setswana | year = 2001 | isbn = 99912-71-21-X}} ==External links== {{Portal|Botswana|Namibia|South Africa|Zimbabwe|Languages}} {{InterWiki|code=tn}} *{{wikivoyage-inline|Tswana phrasebook}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110726230507/http://multimedia.peacecorps.gov/multimedia/audio/languagelessons/botswana/Bw_Setswana_Language_Lessons.pdf Peace Corps Botswana: An Introduction to the Setswana Language] *[http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/detail?accno=ED205044 Setswana: Grammar Handbook. Peace Corps Language Handbook Series] *{{Cite web | title = E-books for children with narration in Setswana | work = Unite for Literacy library | accessdate = 2014-06-21 | url = http://www.uniteforliteracy.com/ }} *{{Cite web |title = The languages of South Africa |accessdate = 2014-06-21 |url = http://www.southafrica.info/about/people/language.htm |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110304001836/http://www.southafrica.info/about/people/language.htm |archivedate = 4 March 2011 |df = dmy-all }} {{Languages of Botswana}} {{Languages of South Africa}} {{Languages of Zimbabwe}} {{Languages of Namibia}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tswana language}} [[Category:Tswana| ]] [[Category:Sotho-Tswana languages]] [[Category:Subject–verb–object languages]] [[Category:Languages of Botswana]] [[Category:Languages of South Africa]] [[Category:Languages of Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Languages of Namibia]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox writer | name = Ulf Nilsson | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1948}} | birth_place = [[Helsingborg]], Sweden | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = writer | language = [[Swedish language|Swedish]] | nationality = Swedish | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = 1979– | genre = [[children's literature|children-youth]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} {{BLP sources|date=November 2013}} {{Expand German|Ulf Nilsson (Autor)|date = August 2014}}
'''Ulf Nilsson''' (born 1948 in [[Helsingborg]]) is an award-winning [[Sweden|Swedish]] writer<ref>[http://www.bonniergroupagency.se/Author/Ulf-Nilsson/11847/ Bonnier Group Agency – Ulf Nilsson biography]</ref> who has published more than 100 books and picture books, geared mainly to children and adolescents.<ref>''[[Nationalencyklopedin]]'' biographical entry about Nilsson, retrieved 5 August 2014</ref> He is also the long-running president of the [[Swedish Academy for Children's Books]].
==Books== *1979 – Pojkjävlarna *1982 – Älskade lilla gris *1983 – Lilla syster Kanin (together with [[Eva Eriksson (illustrator)|Eva Eriksson]]) *1983 – En kamp för frihet *1985 – If You Didn't Have Me ({{lang-sv|Om ni inte hade mig}})<ref>{{cite news |author= |author2= |title=Review: If You Didn't Have Me |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/ulf-nilsson/if-you-didnt-have-me/ |quote= |pages= |work=Kirkus |location= |date=1 March 1987 |accessdate=6 August 2014 }}</ref> *1985 – Den fräcka kråkan *1986 – Boeing 747 (together with [[Pija Lindenbaum]]) *1994 – Mästaren och de fyra skrivarna *1996 – En dag med mössens brandkår *2001 – Varg nosar och jagar *1998 – En frälsare är född *2002 – Adjö, herr Muffin (together with [[Anna-Clara Tidholm]]) *2004 – En ängel vid din sida *2005 – En halv tusenlapp (together with [[Filippa Widlund]]) *2005 – Liten mus trycker på knappar *2006 – Den döde talar *2006 – Lilla syster kanin går alldeles vilse *2006 – Alla döda små djur *2007 – Ensam bland rävar
===English translations=== *2015 – Detective Gordon: The First Case, 96pp., {{ISBN|978-1-927271-69-8}}<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nilsson|first1=Ulf|title=Detective Gordon: The First Case: The First Case|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=lEcyBgAAQBAJ&dq=ulf+nilsson&source=gbs_navlinks_s|publisher=Gecko Press|accessdate=7 July 2016|language=en|date=1 March 2015}}</ref> *2016 – Detective Gordon: A Complicated Case, 96pp., {{ISBN|978-1-776570-65-2}}<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nilsson|first1=Ulf|title=A Complicated Case|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=_VzijgEACAAJ&dq=ulf+nilsson&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y|publisher=Gecko Press|accessdate=7 July 2016|language=en|date=1 February 2016}}</ref>
==Awards== Nilsson has received the [[August Prize]] (''Augustpriset'') twice, the only writer for children and young adults to have been so recognized,<ref name="SAC">{{cite news |author= Åsa Warnqvist |author2= Sarah Death |title=New Swedish Books for Young Readers |date=Spring 2013 |publisher=Swedish Arts Council |location= |pages=15 |quote= | url=http://www.kulturradet.se/Documents/publikationer/2013/NSBFYR.pdf |isbn= }}</ref> and a distinction he shares with only four other writers for readers of any age.<ref>[http://www.augustpriset.se/augustpriset-genom-aren Augustpriset genom åren], Swedish Publishers' Association. Retrieved 5 August 2014 {{sv icon}}</ref>
*1983 – BMF-plaketten (jointly with illustrator Eva Eriksson) for ''Lilla syster kanin'' *1984 – [[Nils Holgersson Plaque|Nils Holgersson-plaketten]] for ''Lilla syster Kanin'' and ''En kamp för frihet''<ref>[http://www.sbi.kb.se/en/Resources/Priser-och-beloningar/Priser/Nils-Holgersson-plaketten/ Nils Holgersson-plaketten], Swedish Institute for Children's Books, retrieved 5 August 2014</ref> *1985 – Expressens Heffaklump for ''Om ni inte hade mig'' and ''Den fräcka kråkan'' *1994 – [[August Prize|Augustpriset]] for ''Mästaren och de fyra skrivarna'' *2002 – Augustpriset for ''Adjö, herr Muffin'' *2002 – BMF-plaketten *2002 – Bokjuryn (category 0–6 years) *2006 – The [[Astrid Lindgren Prize]] for his authorship of child and youth literature *2010 – Schullströmska prize for Children's Literature
==External links== {{Portal|Children's literature}} *[https://geckopress.com/author_illustrator/ulf-nilsson/ Ulf Nilsson author biography]
==References== {{reflist}} {{August Prize Best Children}}

{{EngvarB|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{refimprove|date=November 2014}} [[File:Marcia Imperator legs.jpg|thumb|upright|Upskirt photograph showing [[Márcia Imperator]]'s legs]]
'''Upskirting''' is the practice of making [[secret photography|unauthorized photographs]] under a woman's [[skirt]] or man's [[kilt]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-44542051|title=Upskirting ban 'also protects men in kilts'|last=|first=|date=19 June 2018|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref> capturing an image of the [[Crotch|crotch area]], [[underwear]] and sometimes [[genitalia]].<!-- Deviating from the Wikipedia:Manual of Style (WP:MoS), the following quotation marks demonstrate this term is used as a regular noun. --> An '''upskirt''' is a photograph, video, or [[Drawing|illustration]] which incorporates an image made by upskirting.
The practice is regarded as a form of [[sexual fetishism]] or voyeurism and is similar in nature to [[downblouse]] photography. The ethical and legal issue relating to upskirt and downblouse photography is one of a reasonable [[expectation of privacy]], even in a [[public place]].
==Social attitudes== [[File:Fragonard, The Swing-detail voyeur.jpg|thumb|Detail from [[Jean-Honoré Fragonard|Fragonard's]] ''[[The Swing (painting)|The Swing]]'' (1767)]] [[File:Pin-up 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Pin up girl]] The term "upskirt" is relatively recent, but the concept and interest therein are not. Looking up a woman's skirt was depicted in the 1767 painting ''[[The Swing (painting)|The Swing]]'' by [[Jean-Honoré Fragonard]]. In "polite society", looking up a lady's skirt was regarded as [[impolite]] or [[rude]]. In less polite society, looking up a lady's skirt or her lifting up the skirt or otherwise exposing her underwear was regarded as [[bawdy]], as in the case of cabaret dances such as the [[can-can]] or in the case of entertainment involving the raising of a dancer's dress by her spinning rapidly. By the polite society, such behaviour was widely judged as [[indecent exposure|indecent]].
The sudden popularity in the 1960s of the [[miniskirt]] brought the concept out onto the streets, and was viewed by many as mass [[exhibitionism]]. One commentator in the 1960s said, "In European countries ... they ban mini-skirts in the streets and say they're an invitation to rape...."<ref name="Adburgham">{{cite newspaper|last=Adburgham|first=Alison|date=10 October 1967|title=Mary Quant talks to Alison Adburgham|newspaper=The Guardian|url=http://century.guardian.co.uk/1960-1969/Story/0,6051,106475,00.html}}</ref> By contrast, many women viewed the new style as rebellion against previous clothing styles and as [[women's liberation]] of their own bodies. For the first time, many women felt comfortable exposing their thighs, whether on the beach in a swimsuit or in street wear, and were even relaxed when in some situations their underwear would be visible.
Some upskirt and downblouse images originate as innocent fun images which are made with the knowledge and lack of objection of the females affected. However, some of these images can finish up being more widely distributed or being posted onto the Internet without the knowledge and consent of the subject, for example as [[revenge porn]] following a [[relationship breakup]].
Some upskirt and downblouse photos and videos are made specifically to upload onto the Internet, where many viewers seek such images taken surreptitiously (and presumably without the subject's consent). Such photographs are common on fetish and [[Internet pornography|pornographic websites]], as well as on video sharing sites such as [[YouTube]].
Attitudes hardened with the very widespread availability and use of digital photographic and video technology, most recently [[camera phone]]s.<ref name=SeatUpskirt>{{Cite news | first = Maureen | last = O'Hagan | title = 'Upskirt' photographs deemed lewd but legal | url = http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/texis.cgi/web/vortex/display?slug=voyeur20m0&date=20020920 | work = [[The Seattle Times]] | publisher = [[The Seattle Times|The Seattle Times Company]] | date = 20 September 2002 | accessdate = 26 December 2006 | quote = So-called "upskirt cams," sometimes called "upskirt photos" or "upskirt voyeur pictures," are a hot commodity in the world of Internet pornography. }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | first = Jo | last = Napolitano | title = Hold It Right There, And Drop That Camera | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E1D8163CF932A25751C1A9659C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all | work = [[The New York Times]] | publisher = [[The New York Times Company]] | date = 11 December 2003 | accessdate = 23 May 2008 | quote = ... the proliferation of camera phones had helped give new life to "upskirt" or "down blouse" photography. }}</ref><ref name=HAPriv>{{Cite news | first = Michael | last = Tsai | title = Privacy issues plague picture phones | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/Jan/18/ln/ln20a.html | work = [[The Honolulu Advertiser]] | publisher = [[Gannett Company|Gannett Co.]] | date = 18 January 2004 | accessdate = 26 December 2006 | quote = ... because of the growing popularity of camera-equipped cell phones. }}</ref> Such technology was also being used to record upskirt and downblouse images for uploading onto the internet. Specialist websites came into existence where people could share such images, and terms such as "upskirt", "downblouse" and "nipple dress" (i.e., when an erect nipple is evident through the material of a woman's dress) came into use. Of particular concern were images of minors and of people who could be identified. Celebrities were popular victims of such efforts. Issues of privacy and reputation began to be raised.
The creation and viewing of this type of image came increasingly to be described as forms of [[voyeurism]] and pornography. This was not that most of such images were sexual in nature, with most of them being quite innocent by themselves, but because of their association with the nature of the website on which they were posted and because of the size of the collections.<ref>[http://www.ag.gov.au/agd/WWW/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/(CFD7369FCAE9B8F32F341DBE097801FF)%7E8%2BAugInternetPhotosFinalPaperAugust05.pdf/$file/8%2BAugInternetPhotosFinalPaperAugust05.pdf Australia Attorney General Discussion Paper August 2005 - Unauthorised Photographs on the Internet]</ref>
Upskirt photos can be made in a variety of situations, such as when a woman is ascending stairs or getting out of a car or just sitting on a park bench; and downblouse photos can similarly be made in many innocent situations. Upskirt photos are usually taken by a concealed camera attached on the shoe or carried within a bag so it is very hard for a woman to notice that she is being photographed in this manner. There are many methods and types of making upskirt photos and it is very rare for a woman to notice it before actually seeing herself on some of the voyeur websites that display such photographs.<ref>[http://www.voy7.com/voyeurism/upskirt-voyeur/ Blog about upskirt voyeurism and site for sharing upskirt photos]</ref>
==Legal position== Many countries do not have laws which protect a person's right to personal privacy, especially in a [[public place]], but the legal position does vary considerably.
===Australia=== All jurisdictions within Australia have passed laws making it illegal to take upskirt photos in [[public places]] without the person's consent.<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.smh.com.au/news/cameras--videos/upskirting-to-become-a-crime/2006/07/28/1153816375391.html |title= Upskirting to become a crime |accessdate= 10 June 2007 |date= 28 July 2006 |work= smh.com.au |publisher= The Sydney Morning Herald |quote= Voyeurs who secretly take pictures up women's skirts or down their blouses will face a crackdown under draft uniform national laws criminalizing the practice. }}</ref>
===Finland=== In 2010, an elderly man had his camera confiscated and was fined 12 [[day-fine]]s for the act of ''public obscenity'' (which was thought to be the closest match in the criminal code), having taken dozens of upskirt photos in a shopping centre in [[Turku]].<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Naisten takamuksia Turussa kuvannut mies sai sakot ja menetti kameransa |date=5 August 2010 |author=Marko Hämäläinen |journal=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] |url=http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Naisten+takamuksia+Turussa+kuvannut+mies+sai+sakot+ja+menetti+kameransa/1135259115993 |language=Finnish |access-date=14 May 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822020528/http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Naisten+takamuksia+Turussa+kuvannut+mies+sai+sakot+ja+menetti+kameransa/1135259115993 |archive-date=22 August 2010 |dead-url=yes }}</ref>
===India=== In India, under section 66E, of the [[Information Technology Act]], "Whoever, intentionally or knowingly captures, publishes or transmits the image of a private area of any person without his or her consent, under circumstances violating the privacy of that person, shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years or with fine not exceeding two [[lakh]] (200,000) rupees, or with both". The words "private area" mean the naked or undergarment-clad genitals, pubic area, buttocks or female breast. "under circumstances violating privacy" means circumstances in which a person can have a reasonable expectation that any part of his or her private area would not be visible to the public, regardless of whether that person is in a public or private place.
===Japan=== {{see also|Panchira}}
In Japan, some [[Prefectures of Japan|prefecture]]s have laws against upskirt photography.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/05/25/national/kyoto-law-puts-upskirt-photography-focus/|title=Kyoto law puts ‘upskirt’ photography in focus|newspaper=The Japan Times|date=25 May 2014|author=Eric Johnston}}</ref> Camera phones sold in Japan generally make an audible noise when taking a picture, making the person more likely to notice if clandestine upskirt photos are being taken without consent. However, there are also apps that circumvent this by making the camera silent.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2081216/New-silent-camera-apps-cause-plague-voyeurism-Japan.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Rob | last=Waugh | title=New 'silent camera' apps cause plague of voyeurism in Japan - and some are on sale in West | date=2 January 2012}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== In New Zealand it is illegal to make a visual recording of a person's [[intimate part]]s in any setting in which the person has a "[[reasonable expectation of privacy]]". This includes public and private settings. It is also illegal to possess or distribute such images.<ref>[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2006/0075/latest/whole.html#DLM398248 ''The Crimes (Intimate Covert Filming) Amendment Act'' 2006] created offences covering the making, possessing, publishing, importing, exporting or selling of voyeuristic recordings. The punishment can be up to three years' imprisonment.</ref>
===United Kingdom===
==== England and Wales ====
[[England]] and [[Wales]] have no specific ban against upskirting.<ref name="inews_30082017">{{cite news | last = Secret barrister | title = Upskirting: Why a new law is needed to stop mobile phones being shoved up women’s skirts | url = https://inews.co.uk/opinion/new-criminal-laws-rarely-required-law-upskirting/ | work = [[i (newspaper)|i News]] | date = 30 August 2017 | access-date = 3 November 2017}}</ref> When upskirting takes place in public, it is outside of the scope of the offence of [[voyeurism]] under the [[Sexual Offences Act 2003]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Conner | first = Paul | title = Blackstone's Police Manual 2017 Volume 1: Crime | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford, United Kingdom | year = 2016 | isbn = 9780198783053 }}</ref> Nevertheless, prosecutions for upskirting have been successful under the [[common law]] offence of [[outraging public decency]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.croydonguardian.co.uk/news/8894074.Croydon_man_convicted_of_taking_pictures_up_women_s_skirts/|title=Croydon man convicted of taking pictures up women's skirts|last=Miller|first=Harry|date=7 March 2011|work=[[Croydon Guardian]]|accessdate=5 January 2015}}</ref>
In August 2017, Gina Martin, who was upskirted at a music festival, began a campaign to reopen her case after the police closed it; Martin's case ignited a public debate over the legality of upskirting in England and Wales.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-40861875|title=Upskirting - how one victim is fighting back|last=Staff writer|date=9 August 2017|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=3 November 2017}}</ref> The [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] backed her petition, which attracted over 58,000 signatures, to make the practice of upskirting illegal under the Sexual Offences Act.<ref name="BBC_11082017">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40897934|title=Make 'upskirt' photography a sexual offence - Labour|last=Staff writer|date=11 August 2017|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=20 February 2018}}</ref> Following a [[Freedom of information in the United Kingdom|freedom of information]] request created from Martin's campaign, it was revealed that between 2015 and 2017, there were 11 charges related to upskirting in England and Wales, but that only 15 out of 44 police forces held specific records for it.<ref name="BBC_20022018">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43112450|title='Upskirting' should be criminal offence, campaigners say|last=Staff writer|date=20 February 2018|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=20 February 2018}}</ref>
The campaign to make upskirting a specific crime in England and Wales has been supported by [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of the British House of Commons|MP]] [[Maria Miller]], Chair of the [[Women and Equalities Committee]], the [[End Violence Against Women Coalition]], [[Sadiq Khan]], the [[Mayor of London]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.london.gov.uk/press-releases/mayoral/mayors-strategy-to-tackle-violence-against-women|title=Mayor’s record £44m commitment to make London safe for women and girls|website=London City Hall|language=en|access-date=1 June 2018}}</ref> the television presenter [[Laura Whitmore]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Laura Whitmore has tweeted her support for the criminalisation of 'upskirting'|url=http://www.dailyedge.ie/laura-whitmore-has-tweeted-her-support-for-the-criminalisation-of-upskirting-4039589-May2018/|date=28 May 2018|work=The Daily Edge|access-date=8 June 2018}}</ref> and [[Clare McGlynn]], a professor at [[Durham University]] specialising in image-based sexual abuse.<ref name="BBC_20022018" />
===== Voyeurism (Offences) Bill ===== On 6 March 2018, [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] MP [[Wera Hobhouse]] presented a [[Private Members' Bills in the Parliament of the United Kingdom|Private Members' Bill]] to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] in support of Martin's national campaign, which proposed amending the Sexual Offences Act 2003; the bill would outlaw acts of [[voyeurism]], including upskirting.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/bills/cbill/2017-2019/0174/18174.pdf|title=Voyeurism (Offences) Bill|last=|first=|date=6 March 2018|website=House of Commons|access-date=17 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/upskirting-lib-dem-mp-new-law-international-womens-day-wera-hobhouse-sexual-harassment-a8246316.html|title=Liberal Democrat MP tables new law to make 'upskirting' a criminal offence|last=|first=|date=8 March 2018|work=The Independent|access-date=17 May 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> The maximum sentence for the offence would be two years’ imprisonment and in the most serious cases those convicted would be added to the [[Violent and Sex Offender Register]].<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Upskirting to be made criminal offence with two-year prison sentence under proposed law|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/upskirting-law-change-criminal-offence-photos-prison-gina-miller-campaign-a8399286.html|author=Lizzie Dearden |date=15 June 2018|newspaper=The Independent}}</ref> [[Secretary of State for Justice|Justice Secretary]] [[David Gauke]] signalled that the government would support Hobhouse's bill,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/24/new-law-could-made-against-upskirting-uk/|title=New law could be made against upskirting in the UK|last=|first=|date=24 April 2018|work=The Telegraph|access-date=17 May 2018|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> which was later supported by the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]], [[Theresa May]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.werahobhouse.co.uk/prime_minister_backs_wera_hobhouse|title=Prime Minister backs Wera Hobhouse MP's calls to make upskirting an offence|last=|first=|date=3 May 2018|work=Liberal Democrats - Wera Hobhouse MP|access-date=18 June 2018|language=en}}</ref> The bill was not debated at its presentation.<ref name=":0" />
At its second reading in the Commons on 15 June 2018, Conservative MP [[Christopher Chope]] objected to Hobhouse's bill, delaying its passage through the Commons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44496427|title=New upskirting law blocked by Tory MP|last=|first=|date=15 June 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=15 June 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> Chope said that his reason for blocking the bill's passage was in objection to parliamentary procedure rather than to the bill itself: he stated that he would "wholeheartedly" support a government bill that outlawed upskirting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/16296117.Christopher_Chope_exclusive__I_DO_support_upskirting_ban__I___ve_been_scapegoated_/|title=Christopher Chope exclusive: I DO support upskirting ban. I’ve been scapegoated.|last=Martin|first=Andy|date=17 June 2018|website=Bournemouth Echo|language=en|access-date=17 June 2018}}</ref> Chope's actions drew immediate criticism from fellow MPs, including some in his own party.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/theresa-may-disappointed-as-tory-mp-sir-christopher-chope-blocks-upskirting-bill-11405840|title=Theresa May 'disappointed' as Tory MP Sir Christopher Chope blocks upskirting bill|last=Allegretti|first=Aubrey|date=16 June 2018|work=Sky News|access-date=16 June 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2018/06/revealed-conservative-mps-turn-on-christopher-chope-on-tory-whatsapp/|title=Revealed: Conservative MPs turn on Christopher Chope on Tory WhatsApp {{!}} Coffee House|last=|first=|date=15 June 2018|work=The Spectator Coffee House|access-date=17 June 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> May also expressed her disappointment at the objection.<ref name=":3" /> In protest at his actions, staff at the House of Commons placed a [[Bunting (textile)|bunting]] of women's underwear outside Chope's office entrance. A similar bunting was also placed outside his constituency office.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44518706|title='Pants protest' against Commons row MP|last=|first=|date=18 June 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=18 June 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> Protestors also confronted Chope at his constituency surgery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/16307492.WATCH__Protestors_confront_Sir_Christopher_Chope_in_Christchurch_over__upskirting__bill/|title=WATCH: Protestors confront Sir Christopher Chope in Christchurch over 'upskirting' bill|last=Lewis|first=Jason|date=22 June 2018|website=Bournemouth Echo|language=en|access-date=24 June 2018}}</ref>
McGlynn said that, by being returned to the House of Commons for debate, Hobhouse's bill could now be amended and "future-proofed" to include penalties for creators of [[deepfake]] pornographic images. McGlynn said that the bill as drafted had "placed too high a burden of proof on prosecutors because they had to show that a picture was taken for the purposes of sexual gratification or to cause distress" when "the unfortunate reality is that these things are often done 'for a laugh'. It's not clear to me that the current proposed legislation will cover these situations."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/21/call-for-upskirting-bill-to-include-deepfake-pornography-ban|title=Call for upskirting bill to include 'deepfake' pornography ban|last1=Sabbagh|first1=Dan|date=21 June 2018|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=21 June 2018|last2=Ankel|first2=Sophia|location=London}}</ref>
Following Chope's objection, the government reaffirmed its commitment to introduce legislation to outlaw upskirting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/jun/18/upskirting-government-confirms-plan-to-introduce-ban|title=Upskirting: government confirms plan to introduce ban|last=Crerar|first=Pippa|date=18 June 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=19 June 2018}}</ref> A government bill was introduced to the House of Commons on 21 June 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/weve-done-it-campaigners-celebrate-as-upskirting-criminalised-in-new-government-bill-11412284|title=Campaigners celebrate as government tables bill to tackle upskirting|last=Bradley|first=Sorcha|date=21 June 2018|work=Sky News|access-date=21 June 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/bills/cbill/2017-2019/0235/18235.pdf|title=Voyeurism (Offences) (No. 2) Bill|last=|first=|date=21 June 2018|website=publications.parliament.uk|access-date=13 July 2018}}</ref> Speaking on the government's behalf in the House of Lords, [[Charlotte Vere, Baroness Vere of Norbiton|Baroness Vere of Norbiton]] said that the legislation would also protect men wearing [[Kilt|kilts]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44542051|title=Upskirting ban 'also protects men in kilts'|last=|first=|date=19 June 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=20 June 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hansard.parliament.uk/Lords/2018-06-19/debates/706FA876-2706-4326-9F3C-F1DF51D19259/Upskirting#contribution-6B888C88-124A-46E2-BD0D-8538CDD355D9|title=Upskirting - Hansard Online|last=|first=|date=19 June 2018|website=hansard.parliament.uk|language=en|access-date=20 June 2018}}</ref> The bill passed its second reading on 3 July 2018.<ref name=":2" />
==== Scotland ==== Upskirting is a specific offence in [[Scotland]] under the Criminal Justice and Licensing (Scotland) Act. This Act, which was passed by the [[Scottish Parliament]], extended the definition of voyeurism to cover upskirting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.scot/Topics/archive/law-order/criminal-justice-bill|title=Criminal Justice and Licensing (Scotland) Act 2010|last=|first=|date=|website=Scottish Government|language=en-gb|access-date=17 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/asp/2010/13/section/43|title=Criminal Justice and Licensing (Scotland) Act 2010|last=|first=|date=|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|language=en|others=|access-date=17 May 2018}}</ref>
===United States=== In the United States, laws vary by state. At the federal level the United States enacted the ''Video Voyeurism Prevention Act'' of 2004 to punish those who intentionally make an image of an individual's private areas without consent, when the person knew the subject had an [[expectation of privacy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s108-1301 |title=S. 1301 [108th]: Video Voyeurism Prevention Act of 2004 |publisher=GovTrack.us |accessdate=27 February 2009}}</ref>
Additionally, many state laws address the issue as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncvc.org/ncvc/AGP.Net/Components/documentViewer/Download.aspxnz?DocumentID=40459|title=Video Voyeurism Laws|publisher=National Centre of Victims of Crime|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120624122149/http://www.ncvc.org/ncvc/AGP.Net/Components/documentViewer/Download.aspxnz?DocumentID=40459 |archive-date=24 June 2012 }}</ref>
A 2005 Illinois law made it a crime to videotape or transmit upskirt videos of other people without their consent. A 2014 Chicago ordinance made the crime punishable by a $500 fine.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dardick|first1=Hal|title=Chicago to ban 'upskirt' video taking without consent|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-05-23/news/chi-chicago-to-ban-upskirt-video-taking-without-consent-20140523_1_chicago-city-council-ed-burke-latasha-thomas|work=Chicago Tribune|date=23 May 2014}}</ref>
In March 2014, [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] overruled a lower court upskirt ruling because the women photographed were not nude or partially nude, saying that existing so-called Peeping Tom laws protect people from being photographed in dressing rooms and bathrooms when nude or partially nude, but it does not protect clothed people in public areas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/05/massachusetts-upskirt-court-legal |title=Top Massachusetts court rules 'upskirt' photos to be legal |publisher=theguardian.com |date=5 March 2014 |accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> A law was then passed in Massachusetts to ban the practice.<ref name="blogs.findlaw.com">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.findlaw.com/law_and_life/2014/03/mass-upskirt-photo-ban-signed-into-law.html|title=Mass. 'Upskirt Photo' Ban Signed Into Law|work=Law and Daily Life|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
In September 2014 the [[Texas Court of Criminal Appeals]] voided the state's statute against "improper photography or visual recording" including "upskirt" photos, saying its wording was overly broad. The court's opinion stated: “Protecting someone who appears in public from being the object of sexual thoughts seems to be the sort of ‘paternalistic interest in regulating the defendant’s mind’ that the First Amendment was designed to guard against.”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/19/texas-court-upholds-right-to-take-upskirt-photos |title=Texas court upholds right to take 'upskirt' pictures|publisher=theguardian.com |date=14 September 2014 |accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/crime/oregon-judge-taking-photos-up-girls-skirt-not-illegal/ar-AA95oKA?ocid=mailsignout|title=Oregon judge: taking photos up girl's skirt not illegal|work=msn.com|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
In 2017, actress [[Natalie Morales (actress)|Natalie Morales]] criticized [[paparazzi]] for intentionally taking her upskirt photos and passing them off as her [[wardrobe malfunction]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.womenshealthmag.com/life/a19938130/natalie-morales-upskirt-photos/|title=This Actress Just Slammed Paparazzi For Intentionally Taking Photos Up Her Skirt|last=Bahadur|first=Nina|date=27 September 2017|work=Women's Health|access-date=3 June 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
